doc.title: 2Q NI above BofA but cutting estimates & PO to recognize temporary macro backdrop
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/BofA/2Q NI above BofA but cutting estimates PO to recognize temporary macro backdrop2Q NI above BofA but cutting estimates PO_2025-08-28

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 13,006.00 ARS | Price: 7,650.00 ARS

Net income of AR\\$149bn more than tripled QoQ supported by stronger revenue generation, offsetting higher provision charges. Real loan growth expanded \(82\%\) , while the capital ratio stood at \(30.5\%\) (vs. \(34.3\%\) in 1Q25), remaining the highest among publicly listed Argentine banks. ROAE of \(12.0\%\) improved from \(3.8\%\) in 1Q25, while from an untypically \(- 26.3\%\) in 2Q24. Accumulated earnings in 1H25 of ARrPs279mn implied an ROAE of \(7.8\%\) , at the low- end of the company's guidance range of \(8 - 10\%\) .

Despite better- than- expected 2Q25 results, we are reducing our earnings estimates to reflect the temporary macro backdrop, impacted by electoral uncertainty, the restrictive monetary policy, and the limited peso liquidity across the system. Our estimates reflect Banco Macro to post an ROAE of \(c.6.6\%\) in 2025 (vs. \(8 - 10\%\) guided), implying an earnings contraction of \(20\%\) in 2025. Nonetheless, we expect an average earnings growth of \(c.90\%\) in 2026- 2027 supported by ii) positive real loan growth, ii) stronger revenue generation, iii) operating costs under control, and iv) lower monetary losses from inferior inflation levels. We expect ROE to recover to \(14\%\) in '26 and to \(20\%\) in '27.

We are reducing our PO to ArPs13,006 and the ADR to USD\\$96 (vs. ArPs14,790 and USD\\$118 before) mainly to reflect i) our new net income estimates (- 27% on average in '25- 27) - please refer to exhibit 2, ii) a lower sustainable ROAE of \(20\%\) (vs. \(21\%\) before), and iii) constant numbers as of 3Q25. Our ADR assumes ARPs1,350 per dollar.

We believe our new estimates are already reflecting the temporary backdrop, impacted by the electoral uncertainty, the restrictive monetary policy, and the limited peso liquidity across the system. Despite assuming a more conservative approach, we continue to see important earnings rebound over the next years, while we find attractive upside potential of \(70\%\) .
>> Employed by a non- US affiliate of BofAS and is not registered/qualified as a research analyst under the FINRA rules.

Banco Macro is a bank based in Argentina, with focus on low & middle-income individuals and small & mid-sized companies. The bank was created by the members of the Brito and Carballo families who remain major shareholders and has grown to be the private local bank with the largest branch network in the country. Macro is the sixth largest bank in the country in terms of assets and deposits, but the fourth largest private sector bank. The bank is particularly strong in the interior of the country.

Banco Macro (BMA) has an industry-leading capital ratio and a dominant position in the interior of the country. After a challenging 2024- 2025, we expect strong earnings expansion and ROAE around \(20\%\) levels by 2027.

Quarterly Earnings Estimates
Key Changes(US$)PreviousCurrentPrice Obj.118.0096.002025E EPS7.144.122026E EPS10.817.182027E EPS12.179.922025E DPS2.893.16

Loan Growth (+): rose \(+13\%\) QoQ and \(+82\%\) YoY, and came \(15\%\) above our estimates. Positive real loan growth was supported by lower inflation levels. Prior interest rates, and low credit penetration. Strong lending dynamics were notable in the financial sector and in the private sector, such as overdrafts, discounted documents, mortgages, pledge and personal loans, and credit cards.

Net interest Income (+): NII advanced \(1630\%\) YoY (+14% QoQ) and came \(5\%\) above our expectations mainly explained by a larger loan book expansion and higher yield on earning assets (in both loans and government securities). Furthermore, NIM expanded \(+30bp\) QoQ to \(23.5\%\) driven by interest on loans and interest from government securities.

Asset Quality (- ): NPL ratio deteriorated by \(+60bp\) QoQ to \(2.1\%\) , mainly explained by a deterioration of \(+100bp\) in the retail portfolio (to \(2.8\%\) ), although partially offset by an improvement of - 20bp in the commercial portfolio (to \(0.5\%\) ). Consequently, provision charges were \(4.5x\) higher YoY (+47% QoQ) and came \(4\%\) above our expectations. Cost of risk of \(5.0\%\) of average gross loans, increased from \(4.1\%\) in 1Q25, explained by the expansion of the loan portfolio based on expected losses. With higher NPL deterioration, the reserve coverage ratio declined to \(140\%\) from \(163\%\) in 1Q25.

Fees (+): advanced \(34\%\) YoY (+16% QoQ), and came in \(15\%\) above our estimates, driven by fees charged on deposit accounts, credit card fees, credit related fees, and collection services from financial provinces.

Opex (=): kept unchanged YoY and advanced only \(2\%\) QoQ (in- line with BofAe), explained by i) lower employee remunerations and social security contributions, and ii) inferior administrative expenses related to taxes, electricity & communications, rental agreements, and stationary & office supplies.
Tax rate (+): declined to \(39\%\) from \(43\%\) in 1Q25 reflecting better tax gains.
Exhibit 1: Banco Macro - 2Q25 results 2Q25 earnings came better-than-expected supported by stronger revenue generation, offsetting provision charges
Source: Company data and BofA Global Research estimates

We forecast earnings contraction of c.20% in '25, although at a slower pace when compared to the contraction of \(77\%\) experienced in 2024, while to expand on average by c.90% in 2026- 2027 to reach an ROAE of \(19.7\%\) in 2027. Key assumptions in our model are:

Earnings growth and ROE: Despite better- than- expected 2Q25 results, we are reducing our earnings estimates to reflect the temporary macro backdrop, impacted by electoral uncertainty, the restrictive monetary policy, and the limited peso liquidity across the system. Our estimates reflect Banco Macro to post an ROAE of c.6.6% in 2025 (vs. \(8 - 10\%\) guided), implying an earnings contraction of \(20\%\) in 2025. Nonetheless, we expect an average earnings growth of c.90% in 2026- 2027 supported by ii) positive real loan growth, ii) stronger revenue generation, iii) operating costs under control, and iv) lower monetary losses from inferior inflation levels. We expect ROE to recover to \(14\%\) in 2026 and to \(20\%\) in 2027.

Loan growth: We estimate \(50\%\) loan growth in 2025 (below the company's guidance of \(60\%\) ), reflecting a temporary backdrop, impacted by the volatility on interest rates experienced in late July and August, the restrictive monetary policy, and the limited peso liquidity across the system. Meanwhile, we expect lending activity of \(30\%\) in 2026- 2027 supported by investments post- election, and a still low credit penetration in the country.

Loan to deposit ratio: Our estimates assume LDR to normalize to c.88% levels in 2025 (vs. \(73\%\) in 2024). Year- end LDR is lower when compared to \(91.8\%\) in 2Q25, as we expect cautiously lending origination in 2H25 due to the mid- term elections next October. Meanwhile, we expect LDR to reach \(97\%\) in 2026 and \(98\%\) in 2027. Importantly, Banco Macro remains with the highest CET1 ratio among Mexican banks, which will help the bank to continue expanding the loan book.

Loans to total assets: loans represented \(43\%\) of total assets in 2024, while they stood at \(53\%\) in 2Q25. We expect them to remain at \(53\%\) of total assets by year- end given our estimates assume softer loan growth of \(50\%\) (vs. \(60\%\) before). Meanwhile, we expect them to represent \(60\%\) in 2026 and \(64\%\) in 2027, of total assets, respectively.

NII: We expect NII growth of \(43\%\) YoY in 2025 (vs. \(- 10\%\) in 2024). NII growth should be driven by a higher yield on earnings assets and strong real loan growth. We think Banco Macro would be translating higher funding costs from debt auctions experienced in July/August to their clients, particularly in personal loans which entail 3- year maturity. Meanwhile, we expect average NII growth of \(13\%\) in 2026- 2027 by shifting the asset mix, reflecting lower gains from investment securities but stronger financial interests from loan book expansion.
Fees: we forecast growth above inflation in 2025, while \(2\%\) growth in the next years, supported by higher credit/debit transactions.
Operating expenses: we forecast opex growth below inflation supported by management's efficiencies in headcount and branches. Meanwhile, we expect modest opex growth above inflation in 2027.

NPL ratio: we expect NPL ratio deterioration of \(+130bp\) in 2025 (to \(2.5\%\) ), and deteriorations of \(+10 - 20bp\) per year in '26- 27 (to \(2.6 / 2.8\%\) ), due to the loan book expansion. We believe our estimates already assume a bearish scenario given NPL ratio is already above pre- pandemic levels of \(1.7\%\) observed during 2017- 2019.

- Provision charges: We expect provisions to average loans of \(6.1\%\) in 2025 (vs. \(5.0\%\) in 2Q25), while gradually normalizing to \(5.8 / 4.5\%\) in '26-27, within a context of a more normalized economy and the discussion of potential structural reforms after October's mid-term election. Our 2026-2027 estimates assume a bearish scenario, as our cost of risk estimate will above \(2.0\%\) observed in the 2017-2019 period.
- Effective tax rate: We expect an effective tax rate of \(39\%\) in the next years.

- Dividend payment: our estimates reflect the approved dividend payment of 10 monthly installments since June 2025 and ending in March 2026, implying a total dividend pay-out ratio of \(88\%\) (61% in 2025). We expect the remaining \(26\%\) pay-out ratio of March 2026 plus an ordinary dividend pay-out ratio of \(20\%\) in 2Q26. Meanwhile, we expect dividend pay-out ratio of \(20\%\) in 2027.
- ROAE: Our estimates assume \(6.6\%\) ROAE in '25 (already below the company's guidance of \(8 - 10\%\) ), while we expect a sustainable ROAE of \(c.20\%\) by 2027.
NI: Net Income  NII: Net Interest Income  NIM: Net Interest Margin  LDR: Loan-to-deposit ratio  ROAE: Average Return on Equity
Exhibit 2: Banco Macro - Changes in earnings estimates Cutting our earnings estimates on average by \(-27\%\) in 2025-2027 mainly to reflect higher opex and provision charges
Source: Company data and BofA Global Research estimates

We are reducing our POs to ArPs13,006 and the ADR to USD\\$96 (vs. ArPs14,790 and USD\\$118 before) mainly to reflect i) our new net income estimates (- 27% on average in '25- 27)- - please refer to exhibit 2, ii) a lower sustainable ROAE of 20% (vs. 21% before), and iii) constant numbers as of 3Q25. Our ADR assumes ARPs1,350 per dollar.

Our new PO is derived from the Gordon Growth Model, assuming 4% growth in perpetuity and a sustainable ROE of 19.7%. Our COE of 15.7% reflects a US risk- free rate of 4.0%, Argentine country risk of 300bp (well below the 10Y CDS), inflation differential of 3.0%, a beta of 1.0x, and an equity risk premium of 570bp.

Our price objective of ArPs13,006/share (US\\$96/ADR converted at 1,350 FX rate) is derived from the Gordon Growth Model, assuming a COE of \(15.7\%\) (reflecting a US riskfree rate of \(4.00\%\) , Argentina country risk of 300bp, inflation differential of 300bp and beta of \(1.0x\) ), \(9\%\) growth in perpetuity and a sustainable ROE of \(20\%\) .

Downside risks are: 1) execution risk, as the bank transitions from a high inflation and high interest rate environment, and 2) asset quality deterioration. Upside risks are: 1) stronger loan growth, 2) improved asset quality, and 3) lower inflation levels.

Our price objective of ArPs13,006/share (US\\$96/ADR converted at 1,350 FX rate) is derived from the Gordon Growth Model, assuming a COE of \(15.7\%\) (reflecting a US riskfree rate of \(4.00\%\) , Argentina country risk of 300bp, inflation differential of 300bp and beta of \(1.0x\) ), \(9\%\) growth in perpetuity and a sustainable ROE of \(20\%\) .

Downside risks are: 1) execution risk, as the bank transitions from a high inflation and high interest rate environment, and 2) asset quality deterioration. Upside risks are: 1) stronger loan growth, 2) improved asset quality, and 3) lower inflation levels.

Qmethod is the set of BofA Global Research standard measures that serve to maintain global consistency under three broad headings: Business Performance, Quality of Earnings, and validations. The key features of iMethod are: A consistently structured, detailed, and transparent methodology. Guidelines to maximize the effectiveness of the comparative valuation process, and to identify some common pitfalls. tates is our real-time global research database that is sourced directly from our equity analysts earnings models and includes forecasted as well as historical data for income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements for companies covered by BofA Global Research.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
